title: Should you trust unanimous decisions? - Derek Abbott

multiple-choice.question: What is the paradox of unanimity?

options.label: A
options.text: The phenomenon where the closer a group reaches total agreement, the more reliable the result becomes.

options.label: B
options.text: The phenomenon where the closer a group reaches total agreement, the less reliable the result becomes.

options.label: C
options.text: The phenomenon where the closer a group reaches total disagreement, the more reliable the result becomes.

options.label: D
options.text: The phenomenon where the closer a group reaches total agreement, the more uncertain the result becomes.

multiple-choice.question: What type of situations are often affected by the paradox of unanimity?

options.label: A
options.text: Situations with very low levels of uncertainty.

options.label: B
options.text: Situations with high levels of uncertainty.

options.label: C
options.text: Situations with moderate levels of uncertainty.

multiple-choice.question: According to a 1994 study, what percentage of witnesses tend to pick the wrong person out of a lineup?
Why can memory based on short glimpses be unreliable?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is based on a long period of observation.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is based on a short period of observation.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is based on a combination of observation and deduction.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is based on a combination of observation and intuition.

multiple-choice.question: What type of error can arise through deliberate fraud?
What was the outcome of the 2002 presidential referendum held by Saddam Hussein?

options.label: A
options.text: A 100% turnout with all voters supposedly voting in favor of another seven-year term.

options.label: B
options.text: A 50% turnout with all voters supposedly voting in favor of another seven-year term.

options.label: C
options.text: A 100% turnout with all voters supposedly voting against another seven-year term.

options.label: D
options.text: A 50% turnout with all voters supposedly voting against another seven-year term.

multiple-choice.question: What should a unanimous verdict in a situation with high levels of uncertainty indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: That the result is highly reliable.

options.label: B
options.text: That the result is highly uncertain.

options.label: C
options.text: That there is a systemic error or bias.

options.label: D
options.text: That there is no error or bias.

multiple-choice.question: What is the paradox of unanimity not paradoxical when viewed in this way?

options.label: A
options.text: The fact that unanimous agreement is still theoretically ideal.

options.label: B
options.text: The fact that unanimous agreement is not always possible.

options.label: C
options.text: The fact that unanimous agreement is still theoretically ideal in cases where low odds of variability and uncertainty are expected.

options.label: D
options.text: The fact that unanimous agreement is not always reliable.

multiple-choice.question: What should a perfect result seem like if it is too good to be true?
What is the main point of the paradox of unanimity?

options.label: A
options.text: That unanimous agreement is always reliable.

options.label: B
options.text: That unanimous agreement is always uncertain.

options.label: C
options.text: That unanimous agreement is still theoretically ideal, but in practice, achieving it in situations where perfect agreement is highly unlikely should indicate the presence of a hidden factor affecting the system.

options.label: D
options.text: That unanimous agreement is never possible.

What is a new type of insulation made from recycled plastic waste?

options.text: To monitor and control temperature, humidity, and lighting levels

options.label: A

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the future of sustainable architecture?

options.label: D
options.text: To create a more sustainable future for generations to come

title: Why the insect brain is so incredible - Anna Stöckl

multiple-choice.question: What did Charles Darwin find impressive about the brain of an ant?

options.label: C
options.text: Its ability to function without a head

options.label: D
options.text: Its similarity to the human brain

multiple-choice.question: How does the nervous system of an insect work compared to the human nervous system?

options.label: B
options.text: It works like a decentralized federation

multiple-choice.question: What are clusters of neurons called in an insect's body that coordinate activities like walking and breathing?
What is the primary function of an insect's brain?

options.label: C
options.text: To remember locations of food sources and hives

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon where similar selective pressures cause natural selection to favor the same evolutionary strategy in species with vastly different evolutionary pasts?
What is the study of the comparison between insect and human brains called?
Why is the study of insect brains valuable for engineers?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand how neurons work together in the brain

options.label: B
options.text: To design control systems for various technologies

options.label: C
options.text: To study the evolution of the human brain

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the nervous system of insects

What is the principle behind birds, bats, and bees separately evolving wings?
What is the last common ancestor of humans and insects?

title: What is Minimalist Art And Why Does it Matter?

multiple-choice.question: What was the main style that minimalism rejected in the 1960s?

options.label: B
options.text: Donald Judd, Carl Andre, Dan Flavin, and Sol LeWitt

options.label: C
options.text: Claude Monet and Vincent van Gogh

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary goal of minimalism in art?

options.label: A
options.text: To create complex and intricate compositions

options.label: B
options.text: To remove expression, emotion, and idiosyncratic gesture from the work

options.label: C
options.text: To create objects that drew the viewer in and engaged them emotionally

options.label: D
options.text: To create a sense of nostalgia and historical reference

multiple-choice.question: What type of materials did minimal artists often use in their work?

options.label: A
options.text: Natural materials such as wood and stone

options.label: B
options.text: Machine-made materials such as bricks and fluorescent tubes

options.label: C
options.text: Organic materials such as plants and soil

options.label: D
options.text: Recycled materials such as paper and cardboard

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the term "ABC art" in relation to minimalism?

options.label: A
options.text: It referred to the use of abstract shapes and forms in minimal art

options.label: B
options.text: It referred to the use of natural materials in minimal art

options.label: C
options.text: It referred to the use of machine-made materials in minimal art

options.label: D
options.text: It was a term used to describe the simplicity and lack of ornamentation in minimal art

multiple-choice.question: Who was the art critic who attacked minimalism for being theatrical?
What was the impact of minimalism on the way art was perceived?

options.label: A
options.text: It shifted the focus from the object itself to the context and the viewer's interaction with it

options.label: B
options.text: It emphasized the importance of the artist's intention and personal expression

options.label: C
options.text: It created a new emphasis on the use of natural materials and organic forms

options.label: D
options.text: It led to a renewed interest in abstract expressionism

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary goal of minimalism in terms of the viewer's experience?

options.label: A
options.text: To draw the viewer in and engage them emotionally

options.label: B
options.text: To create a sense of presence and absence

options.label: C
options.text: To create a sense of nostalgia and historical reference

options.label: D
options.text: To create a sense of complexity and intricacy

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the phrase "deliberately uninteresting" in relation to minimalism?

options.label: A
options.text: It referred to the use of natural materials in minimal art

options.label: B
options.text: It referred to the use of machine-made materials in minimal art

options.label: C
options.text: It referred to the artist's intention to create a sense of presence and absence

options.label: D
options.text: It referred to the artist's intention to create a sense of complexity and intricacy

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of minimalism on the art world?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a renewed interest in abstract expressionism

options.label: B
options.text: It created a new emphasis on the use of natural materials and organic forms

options.label: C
options.text: It influenced not only art but also fashion, theater, and design

options.label: D
options.text: It led to a decline in the popularity of minimalism

options.text: The system falls into the same habits over and over again, turning chaos into order

options.label: A
